name.text: 17th Annual CHIRP Record Fair & Other Delights
name.html: 17th Annual CHIRP Record Fair & Other Delights

description.text:
NOTE: WHILE ADVANCE SALES HAVE ENDED, TICKETS ARE AVAILABLE FOR CASH PURCHASE ON SITE.
It's the 17th year of the CHIRP Record Fair! Join us at Plumbers Hall to dig through thousands of crates of vinyl records, as well as DVDs, CDs, posters, and more. It's a music collector's paradise! We've got over 100 tables of vinyl this year - our biggest yet! And you can even get a sneak peek at the records we'll be slinging at the CHIRP records table, to prep for your early admission shopping!
In addition, our lower level will be filled with great food, beer, live music, and multiple Other Delights!

Gear Showcase on the lower level!
Kid's activities up in The Nest, with special programming from the Chicago Children's Museum!
Live music from OVEF OW, The Jellies, Baby Money (solo), DPCD, Thair, and Charming Hokum (Bob Gerics & Megan Donahue)!
Live music and comedy from Groovebox!
Special performances by the Blue Ribbon Glee Club and Reggio the Hoofer!
DJ sets from Van Paugam, Miss Alex White, DJ Chuck Wren, & Metro Chicago founder Joe Shanahan!
Food from Conscious Plates and Taco in a Bag - vegetarian options available!
Beer from Half Acre! Cider from Eris! Mezzo Spritz canned cocktails from Virtue! Wine provided by In Fine Spirits!
Coffee from Metropolis!
First 500 attendees get a free tote bag with download code for the CHIRP Record Fair Local Label Sampler!
Bike valet available, courtesy of West Town Bikes!

Early Admission ($25) begins at 8am and allows readmission all day long. General Admission ($8) begins at 10am. 
The CHIRP Record Fair & Other Delights is sponsored by Discogs!
The CHIRP Record Fair & Other Delights is a benefit for CHIRP Radio. Listen online at chirpradio.org or at 107.1FM on the north side of Chicago!
This year's poster (available through advanced ticket purchase for a discount!) was created by CHIRP's own Annabelle Goldin-Mertdogan!


FAQs
Will tickets be sold at the door?
Yes, though you should know - at-the-door sales are cash-only (ATMs on site), and the ticket lines are quite long in the morning. Buying an advanced ticket will let you beat the rush!
Are there ID requirements or an age limit to enter the event?
Nope! This is an all-ages event. However, we will be checking IDs for beer ticket sales and when said beer tickets are exchanged for drinks. Children under 12 are admitted free with a paying adult.
Are pets allowed?
No, no pets are allowed in Plumbers Hall.
What are my transport/parking options getting to the event?
The Plumbers Hall has a large parking lot surrounding the building, with plenty of spaces. We will also have a bike valet available for cyclists - courtesy of West Town Bikes!
From the Eisenhower (I-290), take exit 28B toward Paulina/Ashland. Head north on Paulina, turn right onto Ogden Ave, then right again onto Washington Blvd - we'll be on the left.
From the Kennedy (I-90/I-94 north of the Loop), take exit 50A toward Ogden Ave. Turn right onto Ogden and head south. Turn left onto Washington Blvd - we'll be on the left.
From the Stevenson (I-55), take exit 290 for Damen. Keep left at the fork to head north on S Damen Ave. After about 2 miles, turn right onto W Ogden Ave, then turn right onto Washington Blvd - we'll be on the left.
From the Dan Ryan (I-90/I-94 south of the Loop), head north past I-55 and exit onto I-290. After a mile, take exit 28B toward Paulina/Ashland. Turn right to head north on Ashland, turn right onto Ogden Ave, then right again onto Washington Blvd - we'll be on the left.
We are also located near the Ashland station on the Green & Pink 'L' lines, as well as the #9, #X9, and #20 buses. We are just over a mile west of the Ogilvie and Union Metra stations, and a little less than two miles east of the Western Ave Metra MD-N, MD-W, and NCS line station.
Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?
Nope! We'll be able to check you in with your digital ticket on your mobile device, or with your name. 
What is the refund policy?
All sales are final. If you cannot attend, a friend or family member may claim your ticket in your name on the day of the fair.
The name on the registration/ticket doesn't match the attendee. Is that okay?
Yes, as long as you can provide the name of the attendee that the ticket was purchased under.

name.text: "Djembe! The Show" - GENERAL PARKING PASS
name.html: "Djembe! The Show" - GENERAL PARKING PASS

description.text:
LIMITED PARKING AVAILABLE |   LOT OPENS 1HR BEFORE SHOW
                                                         
Get ready for an unforgettable and interactive theatrical event, uniting us all in a joyous celebration of music, laughter and life. Djembe! The Show has wowed audiences and critics the world over…and it’s coming to Chicago! Fresh from a smash-hit international tour, Djembe! The Show is making its US premiere at Chicago’s Apollo Theatre in a strictly limited engagement, beginning March 2019.
Chosen by Oprah to lead her SuperSoul Sessions, and hailed by The Chicago Tribune as “a different kind of show—one more in tune with audiences today,” Djembe! The Show is a chance to revel in rhythm with a world-class ensemble of performers. Djembe! The Show combines powerful storytelling and uplifting music into an unmissable theatrical experience. Come feel the energy, emotion and sensational beat of Djembe! The Show.

name.text: Jon Langford & Skull Orchard w/ Dirty Green & Mock Nine/ART SHOW & LIVE MUSIC!
name.html: Jon Langford & Skull Orchard w/ Dirty Green & Mock Nine/ART SHOW & LIVE MUSIC!

description.text:
THE OUTTA SPACE proudly presents THE ART & MUSIC OF JON LANGFORD with JON LANGFORD & SKULL ORCHARD!!! Special musical guests: DIRTY GREEN and Mock Nine!!! The art show will feature Jon's world renowned and legendary bad ass art. DON'T MISS THIS SHOW!!!
JON LANGFORD & SKULL ORCHARD
There's a jolly absurdity in that one of the most important figures on the independent Americana scene and one of the most prolific figures in Chicago's musical community is a guy from Wales who helped found an enduring U.K. punk outfit. But since the mid-'80s, Jon Langford has been a key figure in the nexus between country and punk rock, as well as a vital collaborator with a wealth of musicians from around the world. Langford's career began in 1976 when he founded the chaotic leftist punk band the Mekons, and he would continue to record with them for the next four decades, while they detoured into folk (The Mekons Story), electronic music (F.U.N. 90), country rock (Fear & Whiskey), and any number of other styles. In the '80s, he was also part of the guitar-and-drum machine combo the Three Johns, and after relocating to the United States in the '90s, he formed the celebrated alt-country band the Waco Brothers (best heard on 1997's Cowboy in Flames). From 2000 onward, the prolific Langford recorded with a variety of projects, from the covers-friendly Pine Valley Cosmonauts to the R&B-influenced Four Lost Souls, while also establishing a reputation as a respected visual artist.
DIRTY GREEN


DIRTY GREEN IS ALL ORIGINAL HEART WAILING FOLKIN' PUNKTRY MUSIC!!! .As if from the soil itself, DIRTY GREEN emerged in 2005 and has continued to cultivate a hybrid of authentic, yet truly original music planted deep down in the ground of early american roots. DIRTY GREEN’s namesake comes from a song written by singer/songwriter Aaron Mitchell which pokes fun at the lopsided and fictional attributes of the almighty dollar bill. Influenced by, but not limited to: american folk, Americana, bluegrass, blues, punk and early country, DIRTY GREEN offers a wide array of original ballads, blue-collar rants, pseudo-rockabilly romps, bar room jingles and a hearty batch of heart-wailing folk songs.Vocals/Guitar: Aaron MitchellLead Guitar/ lapsteel: Dennis KardysDrums/percussion: Dean RadzikUpright Bass: Maggie Deagan.


MOCK NINE
Mock Nine is an Indie Rock band from Chicago whose members include Tommy Langford, Franklin Brady, and Mac Campbell, James Bruce, and Sam Grosman

name.text: Nate Smith + KINFOLK welcomed by WDCB
name.html: Nate Smith + KINFOLK welcomed by WDCB

description.text:
DOORS: 6pm  |  SHOW: 7pm
To see a detailed seat map, please choose "Tickets" in the upper righthand corner, select your ticket choices & click "view on map." 

ABOUT THE ARTISTS
Genre: Jazz
Nate Smith's visceral, instinctive, and deep-rooted style of drumming has already established him as a key piece in reinvigorating the international jazz scene, and now his rising career reaches a new benchmark with the release of his bandleader debut, KINFOLK: Postcards from Everywhere (February 3, 2017 via Ropeadope Records). Much like his diverse and ample résumé (which includes esteemed leading lights such as Dave Holland, Chris Potter, Ravi Coltrane, José James, Somi, and Patricia Barber, among others), this album sees Smith fusing his original modern jazz compositions with R&B, pop, and hip-hop.
This leader debut shows Smith at the helm of a core ensemble consisting of pianist and keyboardist Kris Bowers, guitarist Jeremy Most, alto and soprano saxophonist Jaleel Shaw, electric bassist Fima Ephron, and singer/lyricist Amma Whatt, with Michael Mayo on backing vocals. The lineup expands on several cuts with the inclusion of several illustrious guests: saxophonist Chris Potter, bassist Dave Holland, guitarists Lionel Loueke and Adam Rogers, and vocalist Gretchen Parlato.
As the title KINFOLK suggests, the music bristles with a magnetism that can be only achieved by assembling the right musicians, building upon and blending their individual voices and developing a bracing group rapport. Indeed, Smith refers to the aforementioned musicians as "kindred spirits," while embracing some philosophies gleaned from Holland, his mentor. "Dave once told me, 'I really believe that musicians find each other,'" Smith recalls. "He feels that all the collaborations he's done and all the sidemen that he's hired came into his life on purpose, even though he might not have been looking for something specific. He discovers people along the way.
"KINFOLK is about the musical family that I've put together," Smith continues. "All core members of the band have very unique and specific points of view." He reinforces the idea of family by composing tunes that touch upon his childhood: such is the case with the jovial "Morning and Allison," whose title partly invokes Allison Drive, the street on which Smith grew up. The song stars Whatt serenading idyllic recollections of a child enjoying a bright, fun-filled Sunday morning.
Smith recorded his parents - Lettie and Theodore Smith - talking about their respective parents on the mesmerizing interludes "Mom" and "Dad." On the former, Smith's mother tells how her father migrated from Virginia to Detroit and was drafted into U.S. Army, then later returned to Virginia where he bought the family a house. The latter provides a vehicle for Theodore to recall how his own father tirelessly worked at Navy shipyard in Norfolk, Virginia during the Jim Crow era without getting proper financial compensation or promotion until decades later.
"I think of these stories as snapshots that ultimately gave shape to the Black American experience into which I was born, which ultimately informs this music," Smith explains. He goes on to stress the significance of having his father on the disc: Theodore Smith passed away in March 2015. "He never got a chance to hear the music or the band," Smith says.
Smith celebrates the legacy of his paternal grandfather on the haunting ballad "Home Free (Peter Joe)." The song begins with a chamber-like string intro then moves into a gorgeous hymnal melody, highlighted by Shaw's uncoiling of a splendid, blues-soaked lyricism. "Of my four grandparents, Peter Joe was the one I felt the closest to," Smith says. "He was a real buddy of mine. He died when I was only nine but I still think about him a lot."
Smith reemphasizes the theme of nostalgia with "Retold" and "Pages." "Retold" finds Bowers tickling a melancholy yet romantic melodic motif on which guitar and saxophone run parallel lines across. "When I started writing this song, it always sounded like someone telling a love story from start to finish," Smith says. The dreamy "Pages" becomes a superb showcase for Parlato to vocalize the song's theme: turning the pages of a photo album. "I've loved Gretchen since the first time I heard her sing," Smith says. "She becomes a part of the musical fabric. When she sings, it's never about the singer being at the front and the band being way in the back. It's all one sound."
The spirit of the Black Lives Matter movement permeates the somber ballad "Disenchantment: The Weight," another tune that spotlights Whatt's thoughtful lyrics and delicate singing. Underneath the prowling melody, Smith's drums martial rhythms that convey a sense of marching forward. Written in the summer of 2013 soon after the verdict of the Trayvon Martin murder trial, Smith says that the song's cyclical harmonic pattern represents a longing sigh that many people felt and continue to feel after witnessing these ongoing travesties.
Following that aforementioned song is "Spinning Down," an intricate tune marked by multiple subdivided rhythms inside of larger rhythmic cycles. Featuring Holland playing acoustic bass alongside Ephron on electric, intertwining saxophone passages from Shaw; incredible solos from Bowers and Loueke, and surprisingly the only drum solo on the disc, the song touches upon the theme of trying to ease a restless mind. "It works well right after 'Disenchantment' because that song is about everything that's wrong," Smith explains. "'Spinning Down' is about the mind trying to work all that wrong out."
Because Smith didn't come strictly from the formal matriculation of music studies as so many of his jazz contemporaries did, he lovingly describes his approach to drumming as "unrefined," which in turns helps him distinguish his voice. He did, however, earned his bachelor's degree in 1997 in media arts and design from James Madison University. While he was still in college, the legendary singer Betty Carter recruited him for her world-acclaimed Jazz Ahead program.
Smith says that the visual arts discipline he studied in college definitely seeps into his compositions. "I love great movies and images. I've always had a deep interest in composing for film," Smith says. "For this project, there is something very cinematic about the way that I conceived this record. That's why it was so important for me to cast the right characters in terms of musicians. They bring to life the themes of family, nostalgia and identity that define this music." Ultimately, Smith likens the songs on KINFOLK to film vignettes sequenced together to tell a greater story about the unfolding journey of a working artist. This music represents snapshots from that voyage - these songs are the postcards from everywhere along the winding road.
Website 


FAQs
PLEASE CLICK HERE FOR A DETAILED FAQ.
Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event? Unless otherwise indicated, all of our shows are all ages. Please bring a valid ID.
What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event? Residential street parking is free after 6pm Monday through Saturday. Street parking is free on Sunday. Metered parking is free after 9pm. SPACE is located one block east of the Dempster Purple Line Stop. 
What can I bring into the event? SPACE has a full bar with an exciting array of cocktails and an extensive beer list. While we do not serve food in our venue, customers are welcome to bring in pizza from Union, the restaurant up front. No outside food or beverages are allowed inside.
How can I contact the organizer with any questions? For questions regarding your order, please email boxoffice@evanstonspace.com or call 847.492.8860.
What's the refund policy? All tickets are non-refundable.

Nate Smith's visceral, instinctive, and deep-rooted style of drumming has already established him as a key piece in reinvigorating the international jazz scene, and now his rising career reaches a new benchmark with the release of his bandleader debut, KINFOLK: Postcards from Everywhere (February 3, 2017 via Ropeadope Records). Much like his diverse and ample résumé (which includes esteemed leading lights such as Dave Holland, Chris Potter, Ravi Coltrane, José James, Somi, and Patricia Barber, among others), this album sees Smith fusing his original modern jazz compositions with R&B, pop, and hip-hop.

This leader debut shows Smith at the helm of a core ensemble consisting of pianist and keyboardist Kris Bowers, guitarist Jeremy Most, alto and soprano saxophonist Jaleel Shaw, electric bassist Fima Ephron, and singer/lyricist Amma Whatt, with Michael Mayo on backing vocals. The lineup expands on several cuts with the inclusion of several illustrious guests: saxophonist Chris Potter, bassist Dave Holland, guitarists Lionel Loueke and Adam Rogers, and vocalist Gretchen Parlato.

As the title KINFOLK suggests, the music bristles with a magnetism that can be only achieved by assembling the right musicians, building upon and blending their individual voices and developing a bracing group rapport. Indeed, Smith refers to the aforementioned musicians as "kindred spirits," while embracing some philosophies gleaned from Holland, his mentor. "Dave once told me, 'I really believe that musicians find each other,'" Smith recalls. "He feels that all the collaborations he's done and all the sidemen that he's hired came into his life on purpose, even though he might not have been looking for something specific. He discovers people along the way.

"KINFOLK is about the musical family that I've put together," Smith continues. "All core members of the band have very unique and specific points of view." He reinforces the idea of family by composing tunes that touch upon his childhood: such is the case with the jovial "Morning and Allison," whose title partly invokes Allison Drive, the street on which Smith grew up. The song stars Whatt serenading idyllic recollections of a child enjoying a bright, fun-filled Sunday morning.

Smith recorded his parents - Lettie and Theodore Smith - talking about their respective parents on the mesmerizing interludes "Mom" and "Dad." On the former, Smith's mother tells how her father migrated from Virginia to Detroit and was drafted into U.S. Army, then later returned to Virginia where he bought the family a house. The latter provides a vehicle for Theodore to recall how his own father tirelessly worked at Navy shipyard in Norfolk, Virginia during the Jim Crow era without getting proper financial compensation or promotion until decades later.

"I think of these stories as snapshots that ultimately gave shape to the Black American experience into which I was born, which ultimately informs this music," Smith explains. He goes on to stress the significance of having his father on the disc: Theodore Smith passed away in March 2015. "He never got a chance to hear the music or the band," Smith says.

Smith celebrates the legacy of his paternal grandfather on the haunting ballad "Home Free (Peter Joe)." The song begins with a chamber-like string intro then moves into a gorgeous hymnal melody, highlighted by Shaw's uncoiling of a splendid, blues-soaked lyricism. "Of my four grandparents, Peter Joe was the one I felt the closest to," Smith says. "He was a real buddy of mine. He died when I was only nine but I still think about him a lot."

Smith reemphasizes the theme of nostalgia with "Retold" and "Pages." "Retold" finds Bowers tickling a melancholy yet romantic melodic motif on which guitar and saxophone run parallel lines across. "When I started writing this song, it always sounded like someone telling a love story from start to finish," Smith says. The dreamy "Pages" becomes a superb showcase for Parlato to vocalize the song's theme: turning the pages of a photo album. "I've loved Gretchen since the first time I heard her sing," Smith says. "She becomes a part of the musical fabric. When she sings, it's never about the singer being at the front and the band being way in the back. It's all one sound."

The spirit of the Black Lives Matter movement permeates the somber ballad "Disenchantment: The Weight," another tune that spotlights Whatt's thoughtful lyrics and delicate singing. Underneath the prowling melody, Smith's drums martial rhythms that convey a sense of marching forward. Written in the summer of 2013 soon after the verdict of the Trayvon Martin murder trial, Smith says that the song's cyclical harmonic pattern represents a longing sigh that many people felt and continue to feel after witnessing these ongoing travesties.

Following that aforementioned song is "Spinning Down," an intricate tune marked by multiple subdivided rhythms inside of larger rhythmic cycles. Featuring Holland playing acoustic bass alongside Ephron on electric, intertwining saxophone passages from Shaw; incredible solos from Bowers and Loueke, and surprisingly the only drum solo on the disc, the song touches upon the theme of trying to ease a restless mind. "It works well right after 'Disenchantment' because that song is about everything that's wrong," Smith explains. "'Spinning Down' is about the mind trying to work all that wrong out."

Because Smith didn't come strictly from the formal matriculation of music studies as so many of his jazz contemporaries did, he lovingly describes his approach to drumming as "unrefined," which in turns helps him distinguish his voice. He did, however, earned his bachelor's degree in 1997 in media arts and design from James Madison University. While he was still in college, the legendary singer Betty Carter recruited him for her world-acclaimed Jazz Ahead program.

Smith says that the visual arts discipline he studied in college definitely seeps into his compositions. "I love great movies and images. I've always had a deep interest in composing for film," Smith says. "For this project, there is something very cinematic about the way that I conceived this record. That's why it was so important for me to cast the right characters in terms of musicians. They bring to life the themes of family, nostalgia and identity that define this music." Ultimately, Smith likens the songs on KINFOLK to film vignettes sequenced together to tell a greater story about the unfolding journey of a working artist. This music represents snapshots from that voyage - these songs are the postcards from everywhere along the winding road.

Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event? Unless otherwise indicated, all of our shows are all ages. Please bring a valid ID.

What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event? Residential street parking is free after 6pm Monday through Saturday. Street parking is free on Sunday. Metered parking is free after 9pm. SPACE is located one block east of the Dempster Purple Line Stop. 

What can I bring into the event? SPACE has a full bar with an exciting array of cocktails and an extensive beer list. While we do not serve food in our venue, customers are welcome to bring in pizza from Union, the restaurant up front. No outside food or beverages are allowed inside.

How can I contact the organizer with any questions? For questions regarding your order, please email boxoffice@evanstonspace.com or call 847.492.8860.

name.text: Hannah Frank Group & Julie Meckler  - in concert at Chimera Loft
name.html: Hannah Frank Group & Julie Meckler  - in concert at Chimera Loft

description.text:
Double up on great live music with the Hannah Frank Group & Julie MecklerSaturday, May 4 at 2948* Central Street, EvanstonDoors open at 7pm Music from 7:30 - 9:30pm
Hannah Frank Group creates a grooving, epic soundscape supporting Hannah’s folk/ roots storytelling and singing. The music takes dramatic turns, from poetic, bluesy mystery to boot-tapping folk ballads and kinetic covers. Hannah’s music has been heard on WLUW and WDCB radio, and the live shows are engaging, intimate and fun. 
 Julie Meckler quit the Parisian stage and landed in New York, June 2008. She bought a guitar and took to the road. The voyage was witness to the birth of her songs. Settling in Chicago she returned to the stage to share her songs with those who would listen. She released her debut album “Queenshead” in 2013.
This is a private event. Tickets are $15, also available at the door.  We have sold out many events, please be sure to sign up early to secure a seat ...Limited to 40 guests. BYOBeverage.

name.text: NEO / Ultimatum / Sleepool / Of Methodist - 新五四 Neo 5-4
name.html: NEO / Ultimatum / Sleepool / Of Methodist - 新五四 Neo 5-4

description.text:
NEO 5-4 新五四: ＮＥＯ w/ Ultimatum, Sleepool, Of Methodist 
presented by NEO at Homan Gardens
Online tickets go on sale to the general public Sun, April 14, at 12:00 p.m.
This is a show put together by NEO as our last show together for a while. We invited our friends Ultimatum 最後通牒, Sleepool 睡池, and Of Methodist to join us to perform for this night before the summer kicks off for real and friends in NEO go their separate ways.
 
ABOUT THE SHOW
Doors at 7.$8 online, $10 at door cash or venmo.
Homan Gardens is located at 3403 W Grand Ave in Chicago,  IL
ACT I: Of Methodist
ACT II: Sleepool 睡池
ACT III: Ultimatum 最後通牒
ACT IV: ＮＥＯ
***We are also looking for visual artists to display their work in conjunction with this show! Fill up our form to apply by clicking here. Apply by 20 April. 
***
ABOUT THE ARTISTS
ＮＥＯ is...a 7-piece band influenced by pop rock, math rock and city pop styles. Their members have come from parts of China, Taiwan, and Singapore, enabling a diverse sound that fluidly weaves through Asian pop, jazz, and blues. They perform bilingually, taking cues from other Asian bands who have made their marks such as Sunset Rollercoaster, Toe and No Party for Cao Dong. Moreover, this testifies to their sense of biculturalism from being in the United States as people of Asian descent whilst finding a means to express themselves creatively and communally.
Of Methodist is…an electronic singer-producer based in Singapore and Chicago. The multi-disciplinary artist created this project as an exploration of his turbulent relationship with Christianity especially in light of his sexuality. Drawing inspiration from Margaret Atwood’s The Handmaid’s Tale in his name, Of Methodist’s work is political, dystopian and emotive. His whisper-like vocals contrast with the smooth and bass driven music that seduces but disquiets with the tension in the political implications of his lyrics. As an artist with a distinct visual fingerprint and direction, his imagery often work in tandem with his music. With visuals, Of Methodist develops a mythos and aestheticism that frames his works to further enhance the experience of listening to his music.Sleepool is…a couple of SAIC students who sought their escape from the classroom and share their love towards a quirky mix of hard rock, pop rock and post rock. Lead singer Jackie started the band along with drummer Pipi, bass player Kelly, guitarists Fanfan and Bacai, keyboard player Ailin and backing vocalist Teresa. The band shares a secret guilty pleasure referred to by the code name KFG.Ultimatum is…a group of people with different backgrounds but the same heart for music. Since they came together in the summer of 2016, they have performed at University of Chicago, Northwestern University, Depaul University, IIT, Columbia College, UIC, and many other business occasions, and wrote or covered over 25 songs. They like to add traditional Chinese elements and instrumentation in some of their songs and experiment with different music genres. They are currently working on original content set to be performed in the near future.
description.html:
NEO 5-4 新五四: ＮＥＯ w/ Ultimatum, Sleepool, Of Methodist 

presented by NEO at Homan Gardens

Online tickets go on sale to the general public Sun, April 14, at 12:00 p.m.

This is a show put together by NEO as our last show together for a while. We invited our friends Ultimatum 最後通牒, Sleepool 睡池, and Of Methodist to join us to perform for this night before the summer kicks off for real and friends in NEO go their separate ways.

 

ABOUT THE SHOW

Doors at 7.
$8 online, $10 at door cash or venmo.

Homan Gardens is located at 3403 W Grand Ave in Chicago,  IL

ACT I: Of Methodist

ACT II: Sleepool 睡池

ACT III: Ultimatum 最後通牒

ACT IV: ＮＥＯ

***
We are also looking for visual artists to display their work in conjunction with this show! Fill up our form to apply by clicking here. Apply by 20 April. 

***


ABOUT THE ARTISTS

ＮＥＯ is...
a 7-piece band influenced by pop rock, math rock and city pop styles. Their members have come from parts of China, Taiwan, and Singapore, enabling a diverse sound that fluidly weaves through Asian pop, jazz, and blues. They perform bilingually, taking cues from other Asian bands who have made their marks such as Sunset Rollercoaster, Toe and No Party for Cao Dong. Moreover, this testifies to their sense of biculturalism from being in the United States as people of Asian descent whilst finding a means to express themselves creatively and communally.

Of Methodist is…
an electronic singer-producer based in Singapore and Chicago. The multi-disciplinary artist created this project as an exploration of his turbulent relationship with Christianity especially in light of his sexuality. Drawing inspiration from Margaret Atwood’s The Handmaid’s Tale in his name, Of Methodist’s work is political, dystopian and emotive. His whisper-like vocals contrast with the smooth and bass driven music that seduces but disquiets with the tension in the political implications of his lyrics. As an artist with a distinct visual fingerprint and direction, his imagery often work in tandem with his music. With visuals, Of Methodist develops a mythos and aestheticism that frames his works to further enhance the experience of listening to his music.

Sleepool is…
a couple of SAIC students who sought their escape from the classroom and share their love towards a quirky mix of hard rock, pop rock and post rock. Lead singer Jackie started the band along with drummer Pipi, bass player Kelly, guitarists Fanfan and Bacai, keyboard player Ailin and backing vocalist Teresa. The band shares a secret guilty pleasure referred to by the code name KFG.

Ultimatum is…
a group of people with different backgrounds but the same heart for music. Since they came together in the summer of 2016, they have performed at University of Chicago, Northwestern University, Depaul University, IIT, Columbia College, UIC, and many other business occasions, and wrote or covered over 25 songs. They like to add traditional Chinese elements and instrumentation in some of their songs and experiment with different music genres. They are currently working on original content set to be performed in the near future.

ABOUT THE ARTISTS
Genre: Jazz
Nate Smith's visceral, instinctive, and deep-rooted style of drumming has already established him as a key piece in reinvigorating the international jazz scene, and now his rising career reaches a new benchmark with the release of his bandleader debut, KINFOLK: Postcards from Everywhere (February 3, 2017 via Ropeadope Records). "Dave once told me, 'I really believe that musicians find each other,'" Smith recalls. "He feels that all the collaborations he's done and all the sidemen that he's hired came into his life on purpose, even though he might not have been looking for something specific. He discovers people along the way.
"KINFOLK is about the musical family that I've put together," Smith continues. "All core members of the band have very unique and specific points of view." He reinforces the idea of family by composing tunes that touch upon his childhood: such is the case with the jovial "Morning and Allison," whose title partly invokes Allison Drive, the street on which Smith grew up. The song stars Whatt serenading idyllic recollections of a child enjoying a bright, fun-filled Sunday morning.
Smith recorded his parents - Lettie and Theodore Smith - talking about their respective parents on the mesmerizing interludes "Mom" and "Dad." On the former, Smith's mother tells how her father migrated from Virginia to Detroit and was drafted into U.S. Army, then later returned to Virginia where he bought the family a house. The latter provides a vehicle for Theodore to recall how his own father tirelessly worked at Navy shipyard in Norfolk, Virginia during the Jim Crow era without getting proper financial compensation or promotion until decades later.
"I think of these stories as snapshots that ultimately gave shape to the Black American experience into which I was born, which ultimately informs this music," Smith explains. He goes on to stress the significance of having his father on the disc: Theodore Smith passed away in March 2015. "He never got a chance to hear the music or the band," Smith says.
Smith celebrates the legacy of his paternal grandfather on the haunting ballad "Home Free (Peter Joe)." The song begins with a chamber-like string intro then moves into a gorgeous hymnal melody, highlighted by Shaw's uncoiling of a splendid, blues-soaked lyricism. "Of my four grandparents, Peter Joe was the one I felt the closest to," Smith says. "He was a real buddy of mine. He died when I was only nine but I still think about him a lot."
Smith reemphasizes the theme of nostalgia with "Retold" and "Pages." "Retold" finds Bowers tickling a melancholy yet romantic melodic motif on which guitar and saxophone run parallel lines across. "When I started writing this song, it always sounded like someone telling a love story from start to finish," Smith says. The dreamy "Pages" becomes a superb showcase for Parlato to vocalize the song's theme: turning the pages of a photo album. "I've loved Gretchen since the first time I heard her sing," Smith says. "She becomes a part of the musical fabric. When she sings, it's never about the singer being at the front and the band being way in the back. It's all one sound."
The spirit of the Black Lives Matter movement permeates the somber ballad "Disenchantment: The Weight," another tune that spotlights Whatt's thoughtful lyrics and delicate singing. Underneath the prowling melody, Smith's drums martial rhythms that convey a sense of marching forward. Written in the summer of 2013 soon after the verdict of the Trayvon Martin murder trial, Smith says that the song's cyclical harmonic pattern represents a longing sigh that many people felt and continue to feel after witnessing these ongoing travesties.
Following that aforementioned song is "Spinning Down," an intricate tune marked by multiple subdivided rhythms inside of larger rhythmic cycles. Featuring Holland playing acoustic bass alongside Ephron on electric, intertwining saxophone passages from Shaw; incredible solos from Bowers and Loueke, and surprisingly the only drum solo on the disc, the song touches upon the theme of trying to ease a restless mind. "It works well right after 'Disenchantment' because that song is about everything that's wrong," Smith explains. "'Spinning Down' is about the mind trying to work all that wrong out."
Because Smith didn't come strictly from the formal matriculation of music studies as so many of his jazz contemporaries did, he lovingly describes his approach to drumming as "unrefined," which in turns helps him distinguish his voice. He did, however, earned his bachelor's degree in 1997 in media arts and design from James Madison University. While he was still in college, the legendary singer Betty Carter recruited him for her world-acclaimed Jazz Ahead program.
Smith says that the visual arts discipline he studied in college definitely seeps into his compositions. "I love great movies and images. I've always had a deep interest in composing for film," Smith says. "For this project, there is something very cinematic about the way that I conceived this record. That's why it was so important for me to cast the right characters in terms of musicians. They bring to life the themes of family, nostalgia and identity that define this music." Ultimately, Smith likens the songs on KINFOLK to film vignettes sequenced together to tell a greater story about the unfolding journey of a working artist. This music represents snapshots from that voyage - these songs are the postcards from everywhere along the winding road.

ABOUT THE ARTISTS

Genre: Jazz

Nate Smith's visceral, instinctive, and deep-rooted style of drumming has already established him as a key piece in reinvigorating the international jazz scene, and now his rising career reaches a new benchmark with the release of his bandleader debut, KINFOLK: Postcards from Everywhere (February 3, 2017 via Ropeadope Records). Much like his diverse and ample résumé (which includes esteemed leading lights such as Dave Holland, Chris Potter, Ravi Coltrane, José James, Somi, and Patricia Barber, among others), this album sees Smith fusing his original modern jazz compositions with R&B, pop, and hip-hop.

This leader debut shows Smith at the helm of a core ensemble consisting of pianist and keyboardist Kris Bowers, guitarist Jeremy Most, alto and soprano saxophonist Jaleel Shaw, electric bassist Fima Ephron, and singer/lyricist Amma Whatt, with Michael Mayo on backing vocals. The lineup expands on several cuts with the inclusion of several illustrious guests: saxophonist Chris Potter, bassist Dave Holland, guitarists Lionel Loueke and Adam Rogers, and vocalist Gretchen Parlato.

As the title KINFOLK suggests, the music bristles with a magnetism that can be only achieved by assembling the right musicians, building upon and blending their individual voices and developing a bracing group rapport. Indeed, Smith refers to the aforementioned musicians as "kindred spirits," while embracing some philosophies gleaned from Holland, his mentor. "Dave once told me, 'I really believe that musicians find each other,'" Smith recalls. "He feels that all the collaborations he's done and all the sidemen that he's hired came into his life on purpose, even though he might not have been looking for something specific. name.text: Eric Lugosch and Phil Heywood
name.html: Eric Lugosch and Phil Heywood

description.text:
DOORS: 12:30pm | SHOW: 1pm

ABOUT THE ARTIST
ERIC LUGOSCH:  Eric Lugosch hails from Philadelphia, but has called the Chicago area home for the past30 years. His early influences include Mississippi John Hurt, Reverend Gary Davis, Doc Watson, and Pete Seeger.
In 1984 Eric won the National Fingerpicking Championship. His first recording, Strike (1986), is an original suite for guitar, flute, and bass. Although best known as a fingerstyle guitarist, he is also a talented songwriter. Making Models (Waterdog Records) demonstrates his bent for incorporating eclectic instrumentation with guitar and vocals. Other recordings include Black Key Blues, which is a collection of original tunes and interpretations of jazz and traditional American music. Kind Heroes and New Tradition contain these same trademarks in addition to original songs. His latest recording, REVision, is an homage tothe late Rev. Gary Davis featuring many lesser-known tunes of the fingerstyle master.
Eric has performed and taught workshops in festivals and concert halls around the world including Stamford Folk & Blues Guitar Festival, England; Wirral International Guitar Festival, Liverpool; Ullapool Guitar Festival, Scotland; Freight & Salvage, Berkeley; Chet Atkins Appreciation Society, Nashville; and Steve Kaufman’s Acoustic Kamp, Maryville, Tennessee. He has shared the bill with performers such as Doc Watson, Taj Mahal, John Prine, David Bromberg, Leon Redbone, Pat Donahue, Duck Baker, Stephen Bennett, and Preston Reed.
Website | Youtube 

PHIL HEYWOOD: Phil Heywood plays fingerstyle guitar with a bluesy swing and a bucketful of whatever it takes to turn an instrumental piece into an arresting lyrical narrative. His lucid playing encompasses the down-home rhythmic groove of a Mississippi John Hurt or Leadbelly, and the sheer fluidity and melodic flair of such contemporaries as Leo Kottke. A soul-satisfying instrumentalist, Phil draws listeners in with his voice as well, singing in a warm, plainspoken baritone that blends smoothly with his rock-solid guitar work.
Heywood has been based in Minneapolis-St. Paul since the mid-eighties, performing locally and regionally. In 1986 he won the National Fingerpicking Championship, and followed up a year later by winning the American Fingerstyle Guitar Festival Competition. Phil has played on NPR’s A Prairie Home Companion with guitar legend Chet Atkins, performed with fellow acoustic guitar luminaries Leo Kottke, Peter Lang, Pat Donohue,
Tim Sparks, and Dakota Dave Hull, and opened shows for such artists as Norman Blake, Greg Brown, John Renbourn, Chris Smither, and John Hammond. He has recorded six CDs: Some Summer Day (1990), Local Joe (1996), Circle Tour (2000), Banks of the River (2003), You Got To Move (2008), and Rollin’ On (2014).
Website | Youtube 

FAQs
PLEASE CLICK HERE FOR A MORE DETAILED FAQ. 
Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event? Unless otherwise indicated, all of our shows are all ages. Please bring a valid ID
What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event? There is plenty of metered parking along both Dempster St. and Chicago Ave., and meters do not need to be fed after 9pm. Residential street parking is free after 6pm Monday through Saturday. Street parking is free on Sunday. SPACE is located one block east of the Dempster Purple Line Stop. 
What can I bring into the event? SPACE has a full bar with an exciting array of cocktails and an extensive beer list. While we do not serve food in our venue, customers are welcome to bring in pizza from Union, the restaurant up front. No outside food or beverages are allowed inside.
How can I contact the organizer with any questions? For questions regarding your order, please email boxoffice@evanstonspace.com or call 847.492.8860.
What's the refund policy? All tickets are non-refundable.

name.text: Sundance Saloon: British Invasion, Tribute to Fleetwood Mac with School of Rock Libertyville
name.html: Sundance Saloon: British Invasion, Tribute to Fleetwood Mac with School of Rock Libertyville

description.text:
School of Rock Libertyville students will amaze everyone when they stage two sure-hit performances back-to-back, The British Invasion and the Tribute to Fleetwood Mac.
Come hear them showcase their talents to cover the music every rock fan loves. 
Music from iconic British Bands from the '60s that took rock music to unimagined popularity. The Beatles. The Rolling Stones. The Who. The Kinks. The Animals. Petula Clark. Lulu. And more.
Add to the that the Fleetwood Mac mega-hits that everyone loves to hear and kids love to perform.  "Landslide." "Don't Stop," "Go Your Own Way," "The Chain," "Hypnotised," "Oh, Well," "Tusk," and many more.
Book your tickets today, support the school, and rock with these great music students.
description.html:
School of Rock Libertyville students will amaze everyone when they stage two sure-hit performances back-to-back, The British Invasion and the Tribute to Fleetwood Mac.

Come hear them showcase their talents to cover the music every rock fan loves. 

Music from iconic British Bands from the '60s that took rock music to unimagined popularity. The Beatles. The Rolling Stones. The Who. The Kinks. The Animals. Petula Clark. Lulu. And more.

Add to the that the Fleetwood Mac mega-hits that everyone loves to hear and kids love to perform.  "Landslide." "Don't Stop," "Go Your Own Way," "The Chain," "Hypnotised," "Oh, Well," "Tusk," and many more.

Book your tickets today, support the school, and rock with these great music students.

name.text: Pacifica String Quartet Concert
name.html: Pacifica String Quartet Concert

description.text:
Recognized for its virtuosity, exuberant performance style, and often-daring repertory choices, over the past two decades the Pacifica Quartet has achieved international recognition as one of the finest chamber ensembles performing today. Named the quartet-in-residence at Indiana University’s Jacobs School of Music in March 2012, the Pacifica was previously the quartet-in-residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and received a Grammy Award for Best Chamber Music Performance. In 2017, the Pacifica Quartet was appointed to lead the Center for Advanced Quartet Studies at the Aspen Music Festival and School. 
The Pacifica Quartet has carved a niche for itself as the preeminent interpreter of string quartet cycles, harnessing the group’s singular focus and incredible stamina to portray each composer’s evolution, often over the course of just a few days. Having given highly acclaimed performances of the complete Carter cycle in San Francisco, New York, Chicago, and Houston; the Mendelssohn cycle in Napa, Australia, New York, and Pittsburgh; and the Beethoven cycle in New York, Denver, St. Paul, Chicago, Napa, and Tokyo (in an unprecedented presentation of five concerts in three days at Suntory Hall), the Quartet presented the monumental Shostakovich cycle in Chicago, New York, Montreal and at London’s Wigmore Hall. The Quartet has been widely praised for these cycles, with critics calling the concerts “brilliant,” “astonishing,” “gripping,” and “breathtaking.”
A complimentary wine reception follows the event.
The program for the Pacifica Quartet will include the following pieces:
Shostakovich: Quartet No. 2 in A major, Op. 68
Beethoven: Quartet in F major, Op. 59, No. 1, “Razumovsky”
Watch the quartet perform Beethoven.

name.text: Sunday Professional Jazz Jam Session at the Eastgate Cafe
name.html: Sunday Professional Jazz Jam Session at the Eastgate Cafe

description.text: How do great jazz musicians and vocalists become "great"? They jam with other professional players during an event that is rapidly becoming an Oak Park institution - the Eastgate Cafe's jam session every Sunday from 4 to 7 PM!  One reason the jam is so popular is that the Eastgate at 102 Harrison St., Oak Park,  unlike other jazz venues, is very intimate. So the audience are next to the musicians and the musicians love it. Another reason is our excellent house band - Doug Lalli on piano, Doug Hayes on bass and John Scoville on drums – is attracting other talented musicians and singers from all over Chicago. Best of all, all of this takes place in a cozy room offering gourmet food - Lobster bisque, Hungarian sausage, Pulled Pork, Salads, sandwiches, fantastic desserts and a full bar! New specials every day and the freshest salads in town. It's the perfect way to end the weekend and get in gear for the upcoming week. Insider tip: come early. Tables can fill up fast. Video:https://youtu.be/i1QKsg4T8so

name.text: South Loop Community Band Concert
name.html: South Loop Community Band Concert

description.text:
FREE ADMISSION!





Please join us for our premier performance at VanderCook College of Music on May 5, 2019 at 6:00pm.





We will be performing:





- An American Fanfare - Rick Kirby


- Prelude, Siciliano and Rondo - Malcolm Arnold


- Cajun Folk Songs - Frank Ticheli


- An Irish Rhapsody - Clare Grundman








The recently established South Loop Community Band (SLCB) consists of musicians from surrounding neighborhoods, VanderCook students and VanderCook alums. The SLCB provides a great opportunity to meet new people, reconnect with fellow alumni, and above all, ensure your performing skills stay sharp.





Directed by VanderCook College of Music alumnus Mike Wallace (BMEd '99), the SLCB rehearses on Wednesdays from 7:00 to 9:00 p.m. No audition required!

 If you don't know, now you know. If you do know, then you know you gotta be there. This 10 piece band will astonish you every time!

Your REQUESTS on the spot! 

A perfect celebration for anniversaries, birthdays, personal celebrations, lover’s holidays or just for the fun of it!
Celebrate with us!!!
Reserved Parties of 10 or more online only to receive a discounted package and reserved seating in the VIP Upper Deck or Front Floor Seats, plus 1st drink is on us for being the Party Host.

FAQs

Contact us at (773) 447-2385
